assessments.ai_justification: The project title, 'Reducing Arrival to triage wait time for Children's Emergency (R.A.C.E.)', clearly and explicitly states the goal. The identification of appropriate team members, leader, and sponsor is also clearly provided, satisfying all criteria for 'Above Expectations'. The Skeptic's point about the acronym being decorative does not negate the clarity of the title's stated goal.
assessments.extracted_quote: Project Title 22 : Reducing Arrival to triage wait time for Children's Emergency (R.A.C.E.) Department: Children's Emergency Sponsors (HODs): Prof Lee Yung Seng, DDON Katherine Leong Team Leader/s: Dr Seo Woon Li, Br Kiren T Team Members: Ms Thilagavathy Periyasamy, Ms Anuradha, Ms Kyi Kyi Aung, Mr Elijah Seah Tzu Hui

assessments.ai_justification: The nature of the problem is clearly explained, stating the lag behind MOH benchmarks, and the scope is well-defined with explicit in-scope and out-of-scope items, meeting 'Meet Expectations'. However, for 'Above Expectations', the rubric requires 'appropriate data collected and presented to quantify and understand the problem'. While the problem is quantified by referencing MOH benchmarks, the actual pre-project performance data (e.g., specific monthly figures before intervention) is presented in the 'Goal' section, not the 'Background'. Additionally, the 'negative feedback from patients' is mentioned but not quantified with specific data from ePES surveys in this section, as correctly pointed out by the Skeptic. This prevents awarding 'Above Expectations'.
assessments.extracted_quote: In the NUH Children's Emergency, the Arrival to Consult time for a paediatric patient is lagging behind MOH's benchmark of 20min (50th percentile) and 60min for 95th percentile. ... In scope: Walk-in patients, P2 Patient journey from Arrival to Consultation... Out of scope: Exclusion of patient segment: Heart & stroke patients, P2 arrival by ambulance (minority cases), Consultation time, Increase in headcount...

assessments.ai_justification: The goals are clearly SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Realistic, and Time-based) with tiered, progressive targets for 'Arrival to Consult' timing, meeting 'Meet Expectations'. However, for 'Above Expectations', the goal must be 'linked to NUH / department objectives'. While improving wait times implicitly aligns with hospital objectives, the document does not explicitly state how these specific targets contribute to broader NUH or Children's Emergency department strategic objectives beyond meeting MOH benchmarks. The Skeptic's argument regarding the lack of explicit linkage is valid, preventing an 'Above Expectations' score.
assessments.extracted_quote: Tiered, progressive target for overall 'Arrival to Consult' timing: 1. In 3 months from workshop: 50th percentile: 30 min, 95th percentile : 100 min. 2. In 1 year, 50th percentile : 25 min, 95th percentile: 80 min.

assessments.ai_justification: The project applied appropriate lean/PDCA tools, including a Value Stream Map, Gap Analysis (Fishbone Diagram), and P.I.C.K Chart, and these analyses clearly link back to the problem of lengthy wait times, meeting 'Meet Expectations'. However, for 'Above Expectations', the rubric requires that 'root causes and main delays/bottlenecks of the problem' be 'well identified'. The Fishbone diagram lists many potential causes, but the project lacks data-driven prioritization or quantification (e.g., Pareto analysis, time studies) to confirm which of these are the *main* delays or root causes. As the Skeptic correctly points out, without such evidence, these remain hypotheses rather than 'well identified' root causes, preventing an 'Above Expectations' score.
assessments.extracted_quote: C. Problem Analysis (PLAN) Value Stream Map (PDF Page 4), C. Problem Analysis (PLAN) – Gap Analysis (PDF Page 5), C. Problem Analysis (PLAN) Brainstorming P.I.C.K Chart (PDF Page 6). Overproduction / Excessive Servicing (PDF Page 4). Lengthy Arrival to Triage Time (PDF Page 5).

assessments.ai_justification: The implementation plan clearly lists solutions, responsible parties, and timely implementation dates (August-October 2023), directly addressing identified root causes, thus meeting 'Meet Expectations'. For 'Above Expectations', the rubric asks if a rapid experiment was carried out, if insights were gained, and if changes started immediately. The document explicitly states 'Rapid experimentation average of arrival to end of triage time = 6 mins' and 'Reduction of 60% !!' from an 'initial prototype', demonstrating a rapid experiment and clear insights gained. The implementation dates confirm changes started immediately. While the Skeptic notes a lack of explicit detail on the *process* of 'Improvement Sprints', the core requirements for rapid experimentation, insights, and immediate changes are undeniably met by the provided evidence.
assessments.extracted_quote: D. Interventions & Action Plan (DO) (PDF Page 7, table with Description, People responsible, Date of implementation from August 2023 to October 2023). Feedback obtained from caregivers as part of initial prototype... Time Savings: Current state average (50th percentile) of arrival to end of triage time = 15 mins, Rapid experimentation average of arrival to end of triage time = 6 mins, Reduction of 60% !!

assessments.ai_justification: The project demonstrates clear significant improvement, with 'All targets met' for both 3-month and 1-year goals. Benefits are quantified (wait times, ePES scores), intangible results are captured through caregiver feedback, and clear charts are used to show improvement. The results are sustained for 18 months, meeting the duration requirement for 'Above Expectations'. However, the rubric for 'Meet Expectations' explicitly asks: 'Are dips explained?'. The 'ED Arrival to Consult Wait Time' chart (PDF Page 8) shows significant fluctuations and dips in performance post-implementation that are not explained in the text. As the Skeptic correctly points out, this lack of explanation for performance dips prevents the project from fully meeting all criteria for 'Meet Expectations' and, more critically, undermines the claim of truly *consistent* sustained results required for 'Above Expectations'. Given the strict grading rules, this prevents a score of 30, but the overwhelming evidence for other 'Meet Expectations' criteria warrants a score of 20.
assessments.extracted_quote: All targets met (PDF Page 8, Section E). Overall, the CE P2 Arrival-to-Consult time has significantly improved and has been sustained for a total of 18 months. (PDF Page 8, Section E). ED Arrival to Consult Wait Time (P2 walk-ins) chart (PDF Page 8). 90% of caregivers said that this is an improvement... 100% of caregivers were supportive (PDF Page 11).

assessments.ai_justification: The 'Strategy for Spreading/ Sustaining (ACT)' (PDF Page 9) outlines a robust plan for audit checks, presentations, communications, and staff engagement, addressing how to overcome potential issues and spread the project within the department, meeting 'Meet Expectations'. For 'Above Expectations', the rubric requires reflection and identified insights/lessons learned. The document explicitly states, 'we systematically updated and fine-tuned our materials to reflect operational changes. This comprehensive update delivered two key improvements,' demonstrating clear reflection and insights gained from implementation. The 'Paradigm Breaking' section (PDF Page 6) also showcases a deep level of critical thinking and reflection on existing processes. This evidence directly satisfies the 'Above Expectations' criteria, despite the Skeptic's call for a more 'formal' reflection, as the evidence of iterative refinement and critical thinking is undeniable.
assessments.extracted_quote: F. Strategy for Spreading/ Sustaining (ACT) (PDF Page 9). As part of our continuous improvement initiative, we systematically updated and fine-tuned our materials to reflect operational changes. This comprehensive update delivered two key improvements. We enhanced our wayfinding system... We also improved visitor navigation... (PDF Page 9). C. Problem Analysis (PLAN) Paradigm Breaking (PDF Page 6).
